required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Mass Balance and Absolute Bioavailability of GLPG1205
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase 1, Open-label Study to Investigate the Pharmacokinetics and Metabolism of GLPG1205 in Healthy Male Subjects Following Single Intravenous [14C]-GLPG1205 Microtracer and Single Oral [14C]-GLPG1205 Administration

brief_summary.textblock: A study in healthy male volunteers to assess how the radiolabelled test medicine is taken up and broken down by the body when given by short infusion into a vein and when given by the mouth in the form of a capsule or tablet.

primary_outcome.description: To determine the absolute bioavailability of an oral dose of GLPG1205 relative to an intravenous (i.v.) microtracer dose of [14C]-GLPG1205

primary_outcome.measure: Recovery of total radioactivity in urine and feces measured as amount of [14C]-GLPG1205 excreted as percentage of the administered dose (Ae%)
primary_outcome.description: To assess the mass balance recovery after a single oral dose of [14C]-GLPG1205

arm_group.description: Single oral dose of GLPG1205 followed by [14C]-GLPG1205 solution for infusion
Single oral dose of GLPG1205 as solid formulation

intervention.description: Single oral dose of GLPG1205 as solid formulation

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male between 18-64 years of age (extremes included) (Part 1) and between 45-64 years of age (extremes included) (Part 2), on the date of signing the informed consent form.
- A body mass index (BMI) between 18.0-32.0 kg/m2, inclusive.
- Having a regular (at least) daily defecation pattern (i.e. 1 to 3 times per day).
Exclusion Criteria:
- Radiation exposure, including that from the present study, excluding background radiation but including diagnostic X-rays and other medical exposures, exceeding 5 millisievert (mSv) in the last 12 months or 10 mSv in the last 5 years. Occupationally exposed worker, as defined in the Ionising Radiation Regulations 2017, cannot participate in the study.
